msDesc.head: A Bernard of Clairvaux, William of St-Thierry, etc.; England or France, 13th century, second half. B Gospel of Matthew with glossa ordinaria, Germany (?), 12th century

physDesc.p: Composite: two manuscripts (pp. 1–350 | pp. 351–446) together at an uncertain date.

binding.p: 17th- or 18th-century binding of leather over pasteboard; sewn on three double bands.

history.provenance: '14' in medieval arabic numbers at the top of fol. vii, the first endleaf: perhaps a pressmark.

It is not certain when the two parts of the volume came together. Part A shows evidence of an earlier binding with rust stains at the beginning from a clasp; but 14th-century (?) annotation on p. 64 of part A resembles annotation on the final page (446) of part B.
history.acquisition: Given to the Bodleian on 7 Oct. 1760 by James Fletcher, bookseller, of Oxford (-1795) (inscription, p. x).

recordHist.source: Description (July 2021) by Matthew Holford. Previously described in the Summary Catalogue (1905). Summary Catalogue, Vol. 5, p. 377

msItem.author: Bernard of Clairvaux
msItem.title: De XII gradibus humilitatis
msItem.rubric: Liber beati Bernardi de .xii. gradibus humilitatis
msItem.incipit: Rogasti me frater .G. quatinus
msItem.note: Followed (p. 130) by:
msItem.incipit: Septimus humilitatis gradus est si omnibus se inferiorem et deteriorem non solum sua ore pronuntiet [Regula Benedicti] Multos mouere solet ista septima
msItem.explicit: Gregorius, uera iusticia habet compassionem, falsa semper indignacionem
msItem.note: On p. 131 is a table of 'gradus', cf. J. Leclercq, ‘Pour l’histoire des traités de S. Bernard’, Analecta Sacri Ordinis Cisterciensis, 15 (1959), 56–78 at 67–69.
msItem.incipit: Corde et corpore semper humilitatis ostendere
msItem.explicit: In duobus qui restant contempus dei

msItem.title: Apologia ad Guillelmum abbatem
msItem.rubric: Incipit apologicum Bernardi abbatis Clairuall' ad Willelmum abbatem
msItem.incipit: Venerabili patri Willelmi

msItem.author: Ps.-Bernard of Clairvaux
msItem.title: De gradibus caritatis
msItem.incipit: Regula dileccionis diuinitus instituta hec est, Diliges dominum deum tuum. Quid est dileccio? Amor. Est amor terrenus et diuinus. Fons unus intus saliens hos duos riuos infundit Caritas igitur gradu primo dilectio est, diuina ab omnibus terrenis ac presentibus prorsus auersa Secundus gradus. Origo eius deus est. Ibi altusalitus, ibi natus, ibi prouectus, ibi ciuis
msItem.explicit: reuerenciam creatori exhibere non desistemus. Explicit.
msItem.note: Also in BnF Latin 1727 fols. 152v-157r, with rubric 'Incipit liber de gradibus caritatis' and final rubric 'Expliciunt tractatus sancti Bernardi abbatis Clar.' (Cf. István P. Bejczy, 'De origine virtutum et vitiorum: An Anonymous Treatise of Moral Psychology (c. 1200-1230)', Archives d'histoire doctrinale et litteraire du Moyen Age 72/1 (2005), 120.) Describes nine 'gradus', each noted with a marginal rubric.

msItem.title: Epistolae
msItem.note: A collection comprising both full letters and centos of extracts, in parts closely resembling the collection in BnF Latin 1727. Rubrics not filled in but guides for most survive in the lower margin.

msItem.incipit: Bernardus abbas de Claraualle Sophie uirgini uirginitatis seruare titulum, apprehendere fructum. Fallax gloria
msItem.title: Ep. 113

msItem.author: 'Eusebius Gallicanus'
msItem.title: Serm. 17 de corpore et sanguine domini
msItem.incipit: Magnitudo celestium beneficiorum angustias humane mentis excedit
msItem.explicit: piis nos operibus preparare dignetur, qui regnat in secula seculorum. Amen.

msItem.title: On the seven deadly sins
msItem.incipit: Septem sunt uicia principalia suie capitalia, que sunt secundum Crisostomum .vii. populi qui terram promissionis Israel promissam tenebant, que sunt .vii. demonia eiecta de Magdalena. Primo uidendum est quid sit inanis gloria, secundo unde dicatur, tercio quod sunt eius species Inanis gloria est inordinatus animi motus, quo quis propriam desiderat excellanciam ut alios honore precellat. Grece cenodoxia est inanis gloria. A suo autem fine inanis gloria dicitur
msItem.explicit: Peccatum contra naturam est quando aliquis extra locum deputatum scienter effundit sanguinemsemen. ecce habemus quod ex .vii. uiciis criminalibus alia oriuntur

msItem.author: Robert Grosseteste
msItem.title: Doctrina de confessione siue De cura pastorali (serm. 31)
msItem.incipit: Scriptum de leuitis scilicet de ministris tabernaculi

msItem.note: Additions on previously blank leaves in an anglicana hand probably of the late thirteenth or early fourteenth century:

msItem.title: Draft sermon
msItem.incipit: Sapientia humiliati exaltabit capud illius [Sirach 11:1] Cum secundum philosophum honor sit premium virtutis
msItem.note: Draft sermon for the inception of a bachelor of theology; begins on p. 263, continues at the bottom of p. 262, apparently ends on the bottom on p. 261, where the text is largely illegible.
Draft sermon on virginity (?).

msItem.incipit: Creatura rationabilis ad hoc condita est
msItem.explicit: et exaltat humiles opitulante domino nostro Ihesu Christo qui

msItem.author: Isidore of Seville
msItem.title: Sententiae
msItem.incipit: Quod deus summus et incomutabilis
msItem.note: Capitula; note in the upper margin of p. 274: Deest prologus
msItem.incipit: Summum bonum deus est

msItem.note: Further additions on previously blank leaves by the same hand as pp. 261-4, faded and often illegible, including (p. 347), text on prayer, commenting on 'Multum valet de precacio iusti assidua'; (p. 348) a letter, followed by notes on 'Qui ex deo est verba dei audit'; (p. 350) another letter.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in plummet for 2 columns of 44 lines. Ruled space 140 100-5

handDesc.handNote: Gothic bookhand (northern textualis), apparently by one scribe. Leaves marked 'W. de B' in the bottom left corner at the beginning of most quires and on some other folios.

decoDesc.decoNote: Spaces left for initials not filled in; rubrication not completed.

history.provenance: In England at an early date, with extensive signs of use: marginalia, maniculae, added running heads, and an abortive attempt on pp. 1-5 to prepare the text for indexing by numbering the columns (1-10) and dividing each page horizontally with the letters a-l at 4-line intervals in the space between the columns.

Perhaps Oxford (?) or Cambridge (?), possibly Dominicans or Franciscans (?). Additions (late thirteenth or early fourteenth century) include a draft sermon for the inception of a bachelor of theology in religious orders, apparently a friar as he is said to have read 'cursorily' on the Bible and the Sentences both ‘here’ and (?) at Lynn and Northampton (hic cursorie tam sententias quam bibliam legit etiam Lenn’ et Norhampton’ ...[illegible], p. 262)
(pp. 236-7) 16th-century pen-trials in English including: Memorandum that I have, rey ey wyd (?), in feather beds in xxx pere of shetts, george (?)

msItem.title: Gospel of St. Matthew with gloss
msItem.incipit: Matheus ex Iudea sicut in ordine primus ponitur
(p. 352) Liber generationis Iesu Christi
msItem.note: The gloss begins with a collection of several prefatory glosses (pp. 351-4). These are followed by a series of lettered glosses in sequences of varying length (A to R, A to P, etc.) linked to letters in the text at the relevant points; the sequence of lettering running across chapter divisions. The lettering ends at the top of p. 372.
p. 446 blank except for pen-trials and mostly illegible notes.
The prefatory glosses are as follows:

msItem.incipit: Matheus cum primo predicasset in Iudea uolens transire ad gentes primus Ebraica lingua euangelium scripsit, quod fratribus a quibus ibat ad memoriam reliquit. Itaque generationi veteris Adę per quem mors intrauit in mundum
Filii David filii Abraham Ordo preposterus ne premisso Abraham
Cum multi scripsisse evangelia legantur soli quattuor
De Thamar. Nota quod in genealogia Christi nulla nominatur mulierum
Tres tesseres cedecades in generatione Christi mistice insinuant fidem trinitatis
msItem.explicit: amari et undosi mundi edidit lucem
msItem.note: Also in MS. Laud Misc. 87, fols. 65vb-66ra

msItem.incipit: (p. 353) Autem genuit Attende hic intermissos reges
Et post transigrationem Babylonis Si ponimus Ieconiam in fine precedentis tesseres
Salathiel genuit Zorobabel Hoc in multis scripturis legitur sed in Paralipomenon
Matheus ab initio euangelii sui, Lucas non ab initio sed a baptismo
Matheus in hac uita qua quattuor temporum curu labitur
Fingunt Iudei regem ex femore Iuda in extremis partibus orientibus reghum tenere
Iuda te laudabunt fratres tui Hoc de Iuda potest accipi

msItem.note: The marginal gloss proper begins and ends:
msItem.incipit: A. Iesus qui uocatur Christus prius ponit proprium nomen Iesus deinde Christus id est rex et sacerdos

B. Desponsata Cur desponsata? Ut per Ioseph origo Marię monstraretur ne a Iudeis ut adultera lapidaretur, et ut uirgo solatio uiri sustentaretur, et ut diabolo celaretur dum putat non de uirgine natum
C. Conuenirent id est nuptiarum sollempnia celebrarent, antequam conuenirent, non quod postea conuenireunt, ut si diceret antequam penituerit morte preuentus est
O. [Cum ergo natus esset] Cum ergo de natiuitate domini in Bethlehem Matheus et Lucas consentiunt
(p. 443, c. 28) Vespere quando primum licuit operari autem sabbati
Vespere autem sabbati Marcus ait ualde mane in quo non discordat a Luca et Johanne

layoutDesc.layout: 27 lines of Biblical text, ruled space for the Biblical text 135 62
Variable lines of gloss, ruled ad hoc, usually in the outer column, but on pp. 351-372 also filling the upper and lower margins.
Ruling in plummet, both text and gloss above top line.

handDesc.handNote: Protogothic book script, text and gloss apparently by one hand; frequent ligatures, particularly in the gloss (ns, nt, us); na, ma in ligature below the line; insular form of the 'post' abbreviation; 'Italianate' abbreviation for final '-us'.

decoDesc.decoNote: 5-line vegetal initial 'M', p. 351; initial 'L' in the form of a bird, p. 352. (P&A i. 67)

history.provenance: In England by the late 13th or early 14th century, as witnessed by annotations in anglicana script on p. 444 and elsewhere.
(p. 414): 'frater Johannes de Rempnam' [Remenham, Berkshire?], early 14th century (?)
Erased / illegible texts or notes on p. 448.

msItem.note: Most of one leaf, bound in sideways to form a bifolium.

msItem.title: Compilatio quarta decretalium
msItem.note: 1.1.1-2 (= X.1.1.1-2, ending at 'mater est et magistra') followed by 2.1.1 (= X.1.3.24), breaking off at 'mandato tibi forsitan', the text beginning on p. x, continuing on p. vii, ix, viii.

supportDesc.extent: Most of one leaf c. 260 190 (approximate size of the leaf as cropped; the height cannot be measured exactly)

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in plummet for 2 cols. of c. 49 lines; width of the ruled space c. 100mm., with 10mm. between columns.

decoDesc.decoNote: Initials in blue with penwork decoration in red.

history.provenance: In England by the later 13th century: annotations in early Anglicana script.
